item.title: Inter-process Communication IPC
item.description: Inter-process communication (IPC) refers to the mechanisms and techniques used for exchanging data and synchronizing actions between processes.

item.title: Basic Synchronization Mechanisms
item.description: Locks Locks are a fundamental synchronization mechanism that allows exclusive access to a shared resource.

item.title: Introduction to Concurrency
item.description: Concurrency in programming refers to the execution of multiple tasks or processes at the same time but not necessarily simultaneously.

item.title: Introducing Ray
item.description: Recently I had a request to match some counterparty names from different files.

item.title: Challenges of Concurrency
item.description: Race Conditions Race conditions occur when multiple threads access shared resources concurrently, and the final outcome depends on the relative timing of their execution.

item.title: Concurrency and Memory Hierarchy
item.description: Cache Coherence In modern computer systems, caches play a vital role in improving performance by reducing the latency of memory accesses.

item.title: Concurrency in Modern Programming Languages
item.description: Java Java provides built-in support for concurrency through the java.util.concurrent package.

item.title: Fetch Operations in Concurrency
item.description: Atomic Fetch Operations Atomic fetch operations are a set of operations that combine reading a value from a shared variable and modifying it in a single, indivisible step.

item.title: Threads and Processes
item.description: Definition of Threads and Processes Threads: The smallest unit of execution within a process.
